thread.title: One in six Colorado drivers ignore seatbelts; State Patrol launches rural blitz
thread.title_full: One in six Colorado drivers ignore seatbelts; State Patrol launches rural blitz

author: Bruce Finley
title: One in six Colorado drivers ignore seatbelts; State Patrol launches rural blitz
text:
State highway authorities are launching an enforcement blitz Monday through April Fool’s Day, targeting rural areas, aimed at reversing Colorado’s declining rate of using seat belts . 
About 84 percent of drivers in Colorado wore seat belts in 2016, down from 85 percent in 2015, Colorado Department of Transportation officials said. And in rural counties, the proportion of drivers wearing seat belts has dropped as low as 70 percent, with 15 mostly rural counties registering below the state average. The proportion of drivers wearing seat belts was 70.7 in Pueblo County, 76.8 in Morgan County and 77.8 percent in Delta County. Pickup drivers and passengers are among the worst offenders, with 24 percent, on average, not wearing seat belts, CDOT officials said — a lower rate of use compared with drivers of other vehicles. 
A similar “click it or ticket” blitz run by the State Patrol in 2016 led to issuance of 1,605 tickets to drivers and passengers in rural areas who didn’t buckle up. Fines for not buckling up start at $65. Parents and babysitters caught driving children who aren’t safe are fined at least $82. Related Articles
